number of helpful: 14 of 31 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												F1 2015 is the next official game of the F1 season brought to you by Codemasters. Last year they announced that, while still releasing F1 2014 in September as usual, they were just going to port over F1 2013 minus classic cars/tracks and alter the looks of the cars (and that they did). They did this because they were focusing on a brand new current gen F1 game that they were intending to release earlier in the year than usual. That game is F1 2015.I've now played 2 hours of it and, combined with my experiences playing the official Codemasters F1 games since 2011, I feel I have a fairly decent insight of the game, so I'm going to go with the typical pros cons approach with some elaboration.So, without further ado. Lets get started!Pros:+ While F1 2014 just felt like F1 2013 without the need to press the KERS button each lap, this game really overstates the changes that were made to F1 in 2014. Less rear grip, more torque, less fuel, harder tyres, and a reduced front wing width. Combined you can really tell the difference and it feels fantastic!+ The game is beautiful. You get to see the tracks in full glory at the start of a race session, but the rest of the game (bar the driver models maybe) looks absolutely fantastic. With a pleasing to look at UI too.+ The game sounds beautiful too. The low pitch roar (lets be honest, it's more like a purr ;) ) of those V6 engines, the whistle of that turbo as it spools up, the sound of the wind rushing past your cockpit, and the squeal of the tyres as your slide them over the curbs. All fantastic.+ Customisation: While F1 games have always been fairly good in terms of customisation this one takes it to the next level. You can request alterations to wing tilt from the pit box during a race! That added, with the new radio chat (though you can not literally speak to your engineer on PC) you can even announce things like oversteer, loss of traction, and your engineer will suggest a course of action. I feel like Jenson Button already!+ In my 2 hours of gameplay I've seen the AI drivers make plenty of mistakes. Which, can be annoying, but it makes it all the more interesting. Max Verstappen lost his rear going round a corner when he caught his wheel on the curb, spinning into me. Maldonado locked up on the entrance to a corner and bumped me in the rear. It's always nice to see AI drivers not being super duper computer driver guys.+ This may seem like a minor point but trust me, it's so good that I feel it needs it's own point. You can finally spectate other drivers whilst in the pits in a quali or practice session! Complete with speed trap speeds and sector speeds. Want to see how your rival takes the track? Now you can!+ The addition of the pre-race on grid line up, an aerial view of every track introducing a race, podium celebrations, and the UI and features inside the pits, you can definitely see that CM went for a more immersive feel with this game and I must say I really like it. Though, podiums make me a bit sad because no career mode.+ CM have given us the 2015 season AND the 2014 season to play with making up for that dreadful F1 2014 game. So we get to enjoy 2014 as it was meant to be enjoyed.+ It's worth noting that I have yet to try multiplayer but I did have a quick look in that section of the menu and it certainly seems there are far more options for matchmaking. Allowing choose skill level of your rivals, as well as picking and choosing various settings and assists to keep the races fair game.+ Again, CM seem to have got the simulation/arcade balance right. The car and customisation feel good enough to satisfy a hardcore racing simer's needs but the game is completely friendly to a more arcade based user experience. This is something CM have done for the past 4 years and they have continued it on with this game.Cons:- No career mode :(. Personally, one of my biggest enjoyments of F1 games is making my own driver, stepping into a lower team's cockpit and working my way up to become a world champion. Sadly, in this game CM decided to remove that possibility. You can still do a career of sorts as an existing driver but it will only be one season (technically 2 I suppose if you do a 2014 season as say, Vettel, and then play a 2015 season as him too...) I have yet to start one of these though so I can't comment on R&D progression or that sort of thing. Oh well, looks like I won't be winning no races this year as myself.- Now I can't comment for everyone but so far I've found the game much more favorable to play with a controller (an Xbox One controller to be exact which, due to windows drivers, is effectively an Xbox 360 controller). I think this is mostly down to my wheel's dreadful pedals though. I figured it was worth mentioning because Retrofly seemed to mention it didn't feel right to him with his wheel. But this one is subject to your own experiences.- Still can't pit manually. Boy I'd love to do that. To make matters worse, when you floor it into the pits (tested at Silverstone) once you cross the pit speed limit line the car instantly decelerates to the pit limiter speed which is very strange to experience. A minor gripe though.- I can't find an option to turn off or reduce HUD. I generally like to play my F1 games HUD free and the addition of the radio chat enforces my preference, but so far the only way I've noticed how to reduce the HUD is to go into cockpit view, and even then it leaves like current position and lap time at the top. Retrofly said there was an option but I haven't found it.In summary, this feels like a massive improvement from the previous F1 game, much in the same way F1 2013 felt to F1 2012. And while I'm disappointed in the lack of a career mode it certainly doesn't lack in content giving you the 2014 season for free. Like I said, to me the game feels more friendly using a controller which has really been the same in all F1 games to date from Codemasters, so if you're looking for a race sim to play with your fancy racing wheel I might recommend something like Assetto Corsa. But if you're an F1 fan looking for a quality F1 racing game to play, or even just looking for a decent racing game that isn't a hardcore simulator as such, this game is probably more suited to you. Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												These are my updated F1 2015 impressions. Codemasters have tossed out every part of their old games and built a new one from scratch. It doesn’t look, feel or sound like the previous titles. It lacks features from the older titles, but the core game is much better than it ever was.Like the other Codemasters F1 games, F1 2015 requires concentration and finesse. I’m playing with a gamepad, and you just can’t mash full throttle and steering and hope to get to the other side of a corner pointing the right direction. The game uses the full possible range of analogue control available to create a remarkably deep and rewarding driving game. It’s the only racing game where I’m happy to drive around the same circuit for 20+ laps, as every moment is unique depending on the tire type, their temperature, the weather, the car damage, and whether I’m starting to feel fatigue. It strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and hardcore simulation, which I feel most simulators don’t hit. Compared to the earlier titles there’s a whole new level of realism, where the aerodynamics and skidding feel just right. When you’re driving on a rainy track and you lose traction, the sensation of sliding on the track is immediately understandable. You can feel how you could have prevented it, and encourages you to do better in the next corner. The way the game communicates what the car is doing to you, even through the imperfect medium of a gamepad, is better than any other racing game I’ve played.Visually it’s easily one of the best games I’ve ever seen, though this opinions appears controversial from what I’ve seen from other players. Like Alien Isolation the game uses several camera tricks that don’t show up in videos because of compression. Thanks to heavy post-process antialiasing and advanced motion blur there are almost no visible jaggies whatsoever. This makes the game look more like a CG movie than a videogame. There’s a remarkable sense of coherence to the visual style. The cars and the tracks appear to be part of a larger world, and objects far off in the distance have a sense of presence that is unusual in games. It feels huge and convincing. This coherence was clearly a goal of the developers, as they’ve made improvements in pit animations. The transition animations between menus, and when you drive out to the track are all much more polished than before. There’s just a couple jerky movements here and there for the sake of speeding up the pace. I prefer how this looks to Project Cars, and any other racing game out now for that matter. The only comparable game is Driveclub. It makes me feel like I’m there, like it’s a real place, like it’s a part of a bigger world like nothing else I’ve played.Other details like the audio has been overhauled. Engine sounds aren’t as in-your face as before, as they now sound as if they travel through the air before hitting you. Same with other sounds like the audience, reflections against walls, and tire noises. They’re all filtered differently based on where the camera is placed, none sounding like simplistic game sounds of the past. A new addition is the wind noise which changes based on car aerodynamics. If you damage the front wing, the air audibly travels differently across the car, making quite alarming sounds if it’s heavily damaged. You can hear the role it plays in keeping you on the track, even if you might not understand it on an intellectual level. This is easily the most advanced racing game sound engine I’ve heard, packed with subtleties that help make the long races more interesting.If you played any of the other F1 games, and have been waiting that next-gen upgrade before jumping in again, this is it. It doesn’t have as extensive career options as before, but the Championship mode will still take you ~20 hours to run a single season, so it’s mostly a loss for those who are in it for the long haul. I’m fine with how this game turned out. In fact it’s better than I dared hope. The depth of the core game mechanics, the coherence to the visual design, the rich audio design, makes this a no-brainer recommendation. I’ve had no technical issues, and most of the crash bugs other people have reported have already been fixed.

content:
1, 2015
												To be fair to this game, it doesn't exactly warrant as much negativity as it's getting. The game was very unstable prior to the hotfix (10/07/15) but is since far more stable and I personally haven't experienced any crashes. The optimisation is class; everything maxed out at 1440p and I never drop below 60fps whilst driving (4790k, GTX 970), though I have heard that Crossfire and SLi don't work.It is a fun game, but the simulation element when it comes to car handling and feel is absolutely minimal, even more 'arcade' feeling than the previous games. I've tried multiple settings with my wheel (Thrustmaster Ferrari F430) and with my Xbox 360 gamepad but I just don't get the feeling that the tyres and track are connected, it actually takes a lot of effort to put the car into a spin, on purpose without dropping down into first and purposefully doing a donut, the car generally feels like it's floating around the track; I play with all assists off.The AI are hit and miss, it seems to vary between practise and qualifying and the actual race; in the actual race, the AI will follow blue flag rules if you're passing some backmarkers, whereas they won't in practise and qualifying. The aggression of the AI has been turned up a notch and it's both good and bad, good because they provide a bit more of a challenge, bad because they'll often just charge straight into you like you're invisible.Some options are missing, such as career and co-op career. The classic career mode I would have liked to see, moving your way up (or sideways) through different teams as you progress through a career for me, added to the all important immersion. It has instead been replaced with 'Championship season' where you take over a real driver and can't change teams, and 'Pro season' where you're locked into a full race weekend with no assists, parch ferme rules, legend AI, full damage etc...The engine sounds are absolutely spot on, the engines sound authentic, but the engineer random babble (he never shuts up!) and the menu music can get annoying.The graphics in my opinion are a backwards step overall, the game looks decent, but not as good as previous iterations in this franchise in certain areas, for instance, I haven't experienced any blocky graphics or texture pop-in, but the cars themselves don't look as good, the mirrors have this strange slideshow thing going on, the AO isn't that strong even when set to X16 and it all has this strange blur effect.As for multiplayer, I can't comment on it as I'm not interested in it for this particular game.So do I reccommend it? Yes and no; it is a fun game, but it is not worth the Steam retail price of £39.99. It would be a fun little pastime to snap up on sale though.

Hi all,Im not a hardcore fan of F1, However i do own all the other F1 titles in the codemasters series & have enjoyed them with a racing wheel.This is my first review I've written ever. So please be kind.  hahaThis new version has the  latest season for 2015, new graphics. great camera angles & terrific replays. AI seems really competitive too.   Graphics look less vibrant & cartoony than the previous versions, it has somre sort of filter on it so it looks like you are watching vision from the TV telecast - if that makes sense?It is missing career mode, split screen racing. Very enjoyable game so far for over an hour I've played it for.I think some people maybe put off by the steep min or max PC specs.  I can re-assure everyone this game plays & looks spectacular even on min specs it will run lightning fast even on 1080P.  I had everything running on high to ultra high as a test - & frame rate was still solidly running on min 50fps+My specs are entry level Alienware Alpha PC console.. -- not too hardcare of a  PC.Base model..Intel i3 2.9ghz (dual core)8 gigs ram (upgraded from 4gb)Standard 5400rpm hdd & GPU provided.Hope this helps in some way.thanks for reading.  Phil

content:
0, 2015
												Not perfect but 2015 makes important strides in areas that really matter. Finally we see independent temp and wear stats for individual tyres for example and at last it feels like your driving style an dpit strategy choices have a gebuine effect. (I will update this review when I have a better feel for tyre changeover dry to wet). The physics model seems much improved, as ever the game is very well optimised and I've not been encountering many of the bugs others have drawn attention to - agin though your mileage may vary. As with any racing game, if changes effect driver performance negatively, that inclines people towards slating the game so do bear that in mind when wading through reviews - the same applies to mine which is written after discovering that the reworked physics and handling suit me very well.The reworked race engineer is an excellent addition, giving genuinely helpful insight and data when you need it. The dynamic weather and track evolution works great also - this is easily my favourite game in the series to date.However, there are some cons. Firstly, the UI can be more than a little frustrating and driver AI seems to have gone backwards against last year, with drivers being often reckless an dunyielding even on out or in laps. The broadcast style commentary is a great touch but sadly it's badly delivered and doesn't seem authentic somehow.Still no ability to design your own helmet or pick your own race number, which seems to me to be a set of features that would require minimal work to implement. Would love to see a custom driver profile and have elements of that reflected in Crofty's commentary. The lack of career mode and safety car are bigger issues and a surprising sacrifice for codies to make, however it's not impossible for these to be implemented later. This doesn't excuse the oversight however. The inclusion of the 2014 season was a nice touch and I think we're all glad Manor made it into the game for release.In summary, I would definitely recommend. However bear in mind it may take a few patches to resolve some of the issues others are encountering so it's hard to be totally effusive wit my recommendation. In any case, the series is moving in the right direction and this is to be appluaded. The game veers more towards sim and less arcade when compared to the previous titles and if that's your bag, you'll be well catered to.

content:
1, 2015
												- AIAI are improved, they will try to keep their position and race side by side. They don't give up as easilly anymore. However they still go double file into the first corner on race starts which is completely bonkers and unrealistic. They are generally more competitive, however they still take some corners unrealistically slow or fast which is a real bummer.- ControlsIt's fine with a 360 controller, infact its very playable. Came 3rd as Raikonnen with no assists against expert AI in my first race. However, when first starting the game it couldn't recognize what i was using for acceleration. I had to go into control setup and rebind everything on my gamepad to make it work. Also there are no deadzone settings within the game (they do exist in XML files though) and the gamepad deadzone is way too small making going in a straight line quite scary.-  GameplayIt plays like the previous games, there really isn't a big difference. People who claim this to be anywhere near a sim have no idea what they are talking about. This is still extremely arcade and handholdy in nature, and thats ok for what it is. If you want a sim go play iracing, AC or RF2, this is a "realistic" game. The only real improvement to the "physics" and i use that term very loosely, is that it's not as frustrating as the previous years because you have a tiny bit more control.No career mode and i don't care. It has seasons (2014 and 2015) single race and time trial. I'm totally fine with that, i'd rather drive as Alonso or Vettel than as myself, seeing my real name in game was always extremely jarring.- GraphicsKinda rubbish, atleast for the requriements that are recommended. The AA implementation is terrible, its a blurry mess. You can turn off the motion blur in an XML file (again why is this not an ingame option?) but there is some seroiusly weird upscaling going on or something because the game looks bad, its like it runs natively at 720p. Also some serious LOD happening as things in the distance don't appear sharp until you are really close, not particularly good for a game when you are doing 200kmh/+ and a object hasn't loaded.- Final verdictIt's a good game at its core. The racing is more enjoyable than previous F1 games and there is some potential here. But its buggy as hell, it crashes, controls don't always work and the graphics are extremely sub par for a PC racing game. Yet i'm still going to recommend this game, but only if you are prepared to deal with bugs. Otherwise wait a month or two and pick it up, hopefully by then Codemasters will have fixed it up.

content:
0, 2015
												I feel like I should start off by explaining what exactly were my expectations for this title. First of all, it is a multiplatform title with a relatively short development cycle, so I certainly didn't expect mindblowing visuals. I also did not expect anything resembling sim-like physics. You can get that in iRacing, don't expect any of that here (or in Project CARS for that matter). I expected more emphasis on physics, however, and on car setups, though not too much. Also, I personally do not care for the career mode or anything of that sort. In all of my previous F1 games I played as Mr. Player One with a plain white helmet. I also expected a reworked AI. I played Project CARS and AC both, and in both cases I was very disappointed with the AI. Especially in Project CARS' case the AI was far too agressive. With that in mind, F1 2015 ticks almost all the boxes in my books. The visuals are solid, though not all that impressive, certainly not as good as Project CARS, but that was to be expected. In terms of actual driving, I was pleasantly surprised with the new physics model. It makes driving challenging, but it leaves you room for mistake, even with no assists on. The flexibility in terms of setups was also better than I expected. You can now change differential settings and there is no arbitrary "ride height" setting, now you change it by altering the suspension settings. For some reason there is no garage setting for brake balance. I am not sure if setup changes actually affect the performance all that much, but so far so good. The AI was by far the biggest improvement in my books. Now it actually tries to defend! AI drivers will at least try to keep their line into the corner, and they are much less prone to sticking to a line which will inevitably lead them into a gravel trap. That being said, they are still remarkably sluggish in the first couple of corners. You can gain a lot of positions there on any difficulty setting. The absence of the safety car is disappointing, but I knew about it beforehand.I have encountered a few glitches, most notably when the game would activate all of the assists when I tried to start a Pro Season. Creating a new save file solved that. As for the performance, I was pleasantly surprised here as well. I was a bit worried when I saw the recommended specs, but my laptop can run the game at very steady framerate (>30fps) at medium-high settings. I have an i7 4700MQ @ 2.4GHz, 16GB of RAM and a GeForce GTX765M. Not a slouch, but not a powerhouse either. Using a G27 wheel I did encounter the problem with weak FFB, but changing the wheel settings, both in-game and through Logitech software, fixed that. I do have a few minor complaints - for example I find the camera angles for looking left and right to be a bit too extreme. Also, I am not sure how to use the new voice commands, and whether they even work on PC. The game did not give me an explanation.Additionally, I have a few complaints about the realism side of things. While I appreciate the attention to detail (for the first time since F1 2011 all of the steering wheels are accurate!), I find it annoying that the game allows you to downshift into neutral and then reverse. Not something that can be done in an actual F1 car, mind you. Also, the Pro Mode is made unnecessarily difficult by the fact that very little race info is displayed on your steering wheel. Things like sector times, lap deltas, fuel levels, brake bias, and so on, stuff that even the most basic racing displays should have, are only accessible through your race engineer, who, at least for me, is only accessible through the convoluted new system that I don't quite understand. The damage model did improve as well - the front wing is a lot more fragile, and the crashes look somewhat more realistic. A lot of people ask for a more spectacular damage model, but Codemasters can’t add it because of the restrictions of the F1 game licence.tl;drOf course this game isn't perfect, but I will go as far as to say that this is perhaps the best F1 game since F1 2010. There are some off-putting points about this game (such as the lack of a safety car), but on the whole I think that this is a very solid release, and I am glad to see the series moving in the right direction.People have been reporting a plethora of glitches, but I've only experienced the one which left the assists on during the Pro Season, and even that is easily fixable. As is the case with a lot of PC games these days, the stability may be hit or miss, but I have not experienced a single crash or major slowdowns of any sort.

content:
0, 2015
												*Guys as a side note, please if you give me a negative review, please explain why in the comments. So I can see how to improve.**It might be worth adding, that I have not had any crashes in my first 6 hours of game time. So maybe if others are having that issue it would hurt their feeling about it, for sure. I can't report that as I am not having that problem.Tldr at bottom.------------------Bugs.There are bugs. The car gets stuck in second coming out of the pits in China for about 3 seconds. The points table somehow reset. etc. The rules regarding what tyres you start on appears to be insconsistant. etc etc.The good?The physics. They are good. No, it is not iRacing. But you can't floor it, you really need to feed the throttle in, especially if it's wet. You need to take care on the brakes. If it's the start of practice you feel how much grip you are lacking because of the green track. And at the end of Qualyfying, wow, just, the feeling of how far you can push the car. When you ace that lap, very rewarding. On the first lap of the long, long race. My god the car feels fat with fuel.The Ai is really good, ok, not perfect, but they actually will fight for position, if they have the inside, good luck keeping your place. The pace is really good through out the races too. If you pit early for fresh tyres, you gain time every lap and you can really feel it. But at the end of that long stint, god help you when your tyres are dead. So it's really interesting to play the longer races, I'm doing 50% fyi. It means you can really put stratagy into play, if you want to be the guy who comes from behind in the last five laps, ala Kamui, you can be that guy.The rain, is really good, the ai slows appropriately (unlike last years game), it really feels like that are driving the same cars. Actually, another nice thing is that the Ai varies their strategies. For example, if it starts raining, most will pit on the same lap, (your engineer will likely advise you to do the same), but some ai will gamble on swapping early or later, you can to and then you really become at the mercy of the rain. Tl:drCons:Bugs.Bugs.No personal names or helmets.No career or custom championship.Multiplayer seems almost impossible to join as of 20 minutes ago.Pro:Really satisfying physics.Real tyre and fuel stratagy.Solid Ai that is fluid.Summary:I only bought this years game because of the steam refund policy. Last years game wasn't good, the phsyics were off, the ai was not impressive. This year, they have really picked up the ball. My first few races have all been challenging, but satisfying. And each race has a story I can tell. There are bugs, quite a few, but, as long as they pull through with the bug fixing, this years looks like it'll be by far, the best codemasters F1 game.Good work codemaster. Don't ♥♥♥♥ it up, fix the bugs.

												This is the first time I've played a game in this series.  It was free this weekend, so I took it for a spin.  Try #1.  I immediately get rear-ended.  Nothing I can try will get the car to move, and I end up getting disqualified.  Try #2.  This time I'm not rear-ended, but the car will still not move, and I get disqualified again.  There is nothing in the two pages of English in the manual to help me understand what I must be doing wrong.  I can change gears.  I hear my engine revving when I press the space bar.  Try #3.  This time we'll do a time trial.  So far so good after rolling start.  The steering is all or nothing, which is understandable with a keyboard.  So I fly off the track, and I'm promptly disqualified.  Again, I cannot figure out how to get the car moving once I've come to a full stop.  At this point, I can't seem to exit the track either, so I just do end task in Task Manager.  There is no try #4.
